positive_phenotypes: Dystonic posturing of arms and legs

num_tested_probands: The proband was the only individual tested for genetic analysis.
The proband was born at term from non-consanguineous parents, and genetic testing was reported for this individual.
The proband was the only individual tested.
The proband was the only individual tested in this study.
num_positive_het_probands: No heterozygous proband was identified in this report.
No proband was found to be heterozygous for a pathogenic variant.
No heterozygous proband was identified in this report.
positive_phenotypes: The proband presented with severe hepatopathy, neurological deterioration, developmental delay, motor weakness, intellectual disability, and epileptic seizure. These phenotypes are consistent with WARS2 deficiency.

Clinical phenotypes associated with the positive probands include severe axial hypotonia, hyper-tonia, dystonic posturing of arms and legs, slight dysmorphic features, delayed cognitive and motor development, decreased awareness, ptosis of the eyelids bilaterally, and severe generalized amyotrophy.
The proband exhibited a range of clinical phenotypes, including developmental delay, motor weakness, intellectual disability, seizures, and Parkinson-like symptoms.
The proband exhibited severe infantile onset leukoencephalopathy, spastic quadriplegia, hypoglycemia (neonatal), epilepsy, and lactic acidosis.
No clinical phenotypes were associated with positive probands.
num_compound_or_double_hets: One compound/double heterozygote was identified in this report.
No compound or double heterozygotes were reported in this case report.
No compound or double heterozygous mutations were reported in this study.
No compound or double heterozygotes were identified.

quote_snippets: mutations in AARS2 in a series of CSF1R-negative patients with adult-onset leukoencephalopathy with axonal spheroids and pigmented glia.
This is the first report of severe hepatopathy in a subject with WARS2 deficiency. The hepatopathy occurred soon after start of sodium valproate treatment.
mutations in AARS2 in a series of CSF1R-negative patients with adult-onset leukoencephalopathy with axonal spheroids and pigmented glia.
She had no head control and rigidity of arms and legs was noticed.
Deep tendon reflexes were weak and both feet were in equinus position.
Hypoglycemia and a slightly increased lactate (which turned out to be normal on the next day) were detected in serum on admission.
Dystonic posturing of the limbs together with motor hyperactivity and continuous choreatic movements were seen.
Concentration of sodium valproate in serum was 18 μg/ml (nl 50–90).
Urinary organic acid profile showed high concentrations of lactate, pyruvate, 3-OH-butyrate, and 3-keto-butyrate.
Acylcarnitine profile was normal.
In CSF, cell count was not increased, glucose concentration was 66 mg/dL, protein 10 mg/dl and lactate 2.8 mmol (nl < 1.7).
Coagulation parameters were perturbed (PT 34%, nl 70–120; aptt 51 s, nl 29–38), direct bilirubin was only slightly increased (0.41 mg/dL, nl 0–0.3) and indirect bilirubin was normal.
Ammonemia was normal (34 μmol, nl 11–48).
Sodium valproate was stopped immediately and phenobarbital was started.
Ophthalmological examination revealed optic atrophy.
EEG and electroneuromyographic examination were normal.
Cerebral MRI showed enlargement of the lateral ventricles and third ventricle presumably due to white matter loss.
Subarachnoidal spaces were abnormally large, most marked in the frontal regions bilaterally.
In the posterior fossa, the vermis cerebelli was hypoplastic, the fourth ventricle was enlarged and the brainstem and cerebellar peduncles were hypoplastic.
No signs of periven-tricular leucomalacia, neither of cystic encephalopathy were seen.
She passed away at home at the age of 6 ½ year.

Light microscopy, cytochemical analysis and electron microscopy showed the presence of Ki67 positive nuclei, macrophages with large PAS-diastase resistant inclusions, CK-7 positive small cells, lipid droplets, and a mitochondrial mosaic.
Biochemical and molecular studies showed significantly reduced activity of complex III and low activities of complex I and IV in liver tissue from the proband.
BN-PAGE confirmed the low activities of the complexes I, III and IV when compared to those in liver tissue from a control.
Single person Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) was performed and variants were filtered using a mitochondrial gene panel based on the Human MitoCarta2.0. dataset.
developmental delay, motor weakness, and intellectual disability
Parkinson-like symptoms starting around the age of one year
acute onset liver failure and severe encephalopathy
hypotonia, severe cognitive and motor delay, cardiomyopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa
Severe infantile onset leukoencephalopathy, spastic quadriplegia, hypoglycemia (neonatal), epilepsy, and lactic acidosis.
Fatal lactic acidosis
Lys31_Gln116del and Val349Leu
